\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
\subsubsection*{template$<$typename T$>$\newline
struct cimg\+\_\+library\+::\+CImg$<$ T $>$}
Class representing an image (up to 4 dimensions wide), each pixel being of type {\ttfamily T}. 

This is the main class of the CImg Library. It declares and constructs an image, allows access to its pixel values, and is able to perform various image operations.

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image representation}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
A CImg image is defined as an instance of the container {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$}, which contains a regular grid of pixels, each pixel value being of type {\ttfamily T}. The image grid can have up to 4 dimensions\+: width, height, depth and number of channels. Usually, the three first dimensions are used to describe spatial coordinates {\ttfamily (x,y,z)}, while the number of channels is rather used as a vector-\/valued dimension (it may describe the R,G,B color channels for instance). If you need a fifth dimension, you can use image lists {\ttfamily CImg\+List$<$\+T$>$} rather than simple images {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$}.

Thus, the {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} class is able to represent volumetric images of vector-\/valued pixels, as well as images with less dimensions (1D scalar signal, 2D color images, ...). Most member functions of the class \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg}{CImg}\texorpdfstring{$<$}{<}{\ttfamily T\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}} are designed to handle this maximum case of (3+1) dimensions.

Concerning the pixel value type {\ttfamily T\+:} fully supported template types are the basic C++ types\+: {\ttfamily unsigned char, char, short, unsigned int, int, unsigned long, long, float, double, ... }. Typically, fast image display can be done using {\ttfamily CImg$<$unsigned char$>$} images, while complex image processing algorithms may be rather coded using {\ttfamily CImg$<$float$>$} or {\ttfamily CImg$<$double$>$} images that have floating-\/point pixel values. The default value for the template T is {\ttfamily float}. Using your own template types may be possible. However, you will certainly have to define the complete set of arithmetic and logical operators for your class.

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image structure}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
The {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} structure contains {\itshape six} fields\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+width} defines the number of {\itshape columns} of the image (size along the X-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+height} defines the number of {\itshape rows} of the image (size along the Y-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+depth} defines the number of {\itshape slices} of the image (size along the Z-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+spectrum} defines the number of {\itshape channels} of the image (size along the C-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+data} defines a {\itshape pointer} to the {\itshape pixel} {\itshape data} (of type {\ttfamily T}).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+is\+\_\+shared} is a boolean that tells if the memory buffer {\ttfamily data} is shared with another image.
\end{DoxyItemize}

You can access these fields publicly although it is recommended to use the dedicated functions \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_aa80be550cee4daa91e5ccf73360b810e}{width()}, \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_aee97615afc19bf3e5f9fb3df72474e94}{height()}, \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a8a876b77c72080e4042aa427e8f86281}{depth()}, \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()} and ptr() to do so. Image dimensions are not limited to a specific range (as long as you got enough available memory). A value of {\itshape 1} usually means that the corresponding dimension is {\itshape flat}. If one of the dimensions is {\itshape 0}, or if the data pointer is null, the image is considered as {\itshape empty}. Empty images should not contain any pixel data and thus, will not be processed by \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg}{CImg} member functions (a \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImgInstanceException}{CImg\+Instance\+Exception} will be thrown instead). Pixel data are stored in memory, in a non interlaced mode (See cimg\+\_\+storage).

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image declaration and construction}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
Declaring an image can be done by using one of the several available constructors. Here is a list of the most used\+:


\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from arbitrary dimensions\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$char$>$ img;} declares an empty image.
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$unsigned char$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(128,128)};} declares a 128x128 greyscale image with {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily char} pixel values.
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$double$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(3,3)};} declares a 3x3 matrix with {\ttfamily double} coefficients.
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$unsigned char$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(256,256,1,3)};} declares a 256x256x1x3 (color) image (colors are stored as an image with three channels).
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$double$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(128,128,128)};} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric and greyscale image (with {\ttfamily double} pixel values).
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(128,128,128,3)};} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric color image (with {\ttfamily float} pixels, which is the default value of the template parameter {\ttfamily T}).
\item {\bfseries{Note\+:}} images pixels are {\bfseries{not automatically initialized to 0}}. You may use the function {\ttfamily \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a91351c659aae7a5175428ec728364fad}{fill()}} to do it, or use the specific constructor taking 5 parameters like this\+: {\ttfamily CImg$<$$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(128,128,128,3,0)};} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric color image with all pixel values to 0.
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from filenames\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$unsigned char$>$ img("{}image.\+jpg"{});} reads a JPEG color image from the file "{}image.\+jpg"{}.
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$float$>$ img("{}analyze.\+hdr"{});} reads a volumetric image (ANALYZE7.\+5 format) from the file "{}analyze.\+hdr"{}.
\item {\bfseries{Note\+:}} You need to install \href{http://www.imagemagick.org}{\texttt{ Image\+Magick}} to be able to read common compressed image formats (JPG,PNG, ...) (See cimg\+\_\+files\+\_\+io).
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from C-\/style arrays\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$int$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(data\+\_\+buffer,256,256)};} constructs a 256x256 greyscale image from a {\ttfamily int\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}} buffer {\ttfamily data\+\_\+buffer} (of size 256x256=65536).
\item {\ttfamily CImg$<$unsigned char$>$ \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(data\+\_\+buffer,256,256,1,3)};} constructs a 256x256 color image from a {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily char\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}} buffer {\ttfamily data\+\_\+buffer} (where R,G,B channels follow each others).
\end{DoxyItemize}

The complete list of constructors can be found \href{\#constructors}{\texttt{ here}}.
\end{DoxyItemize}

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Most useful functions}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
The {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} class contains a lot of functions that operates on images. Some of the most useful are\+:


\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_ae06c89401a8ca898b8bf72b082a1f88a}{operator()()}\+: Read or write pixel values.
\item \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a8ac4e628daa949b3db7456c49f56208c}{display()}\+: displays the image in a new window. 
\end{DoxyItemize}

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

\item Otherwise, the image instance does {\itshape not} allocate a new buffer, and uses the input memory buffer as its own pixel buffer. {\em is\+\_\+shared} & Tells about the shared state of the constructed copy. \\

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a77871bed283c449b2e9ed5624811c68e}{CImg(const CImg$<$t$>$\&)}, except that it allows to decide the shared state of the constructed image, which does not depend anymore on the shared state of the input image {\ttfamily img\+:} 
\begin{DoxyItemize}

\end{DoxyItemize}
\item A {\ttfamily \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImgArgumentException}{CImg\+Argument\+Exception}} is thrown when a shared copy is requested with different pixel types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Access to a pixel value at a specified offset, using Neumann boundary conditions. 

Return a reference to the pixel value of the image instance located at a specified {\ttfamily offset}, or to the nearest pixel location in the image instance in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em offset} & Offset to the desired pixel value. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to at(int,const T), except that an out-\/of-\/bounds access returns the value of the nearest pixel in the image instance, regarding the specified offset, i.\+e.
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item If {\ttfamily offset\texorpdfstring{$<$}{<}0}, then {\ttfamily img}\mbox{[}0\mbox{]} is returned.
\item If {\ttfamily offset\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}=img.\+size()}, then {\ttfamily img}\mbox{[}img.\+size() -\/ 1\mbox{]} is returned.
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Due to the additional boundary checking operation, this method is slower than \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_ae06c89401a8ca898b8bf72b082a1f88a}{operator()()}. Use it when you are {\itshape not} sure about the validity of the specified pixel offset.
\item If you know your image instance is {\itshape not} empty, you may rather use the slightly faster method {\ttfamily \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a5aa6de1cb4b1f452136f39702feb8b2d}{\+\_\+at(int)}}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Access to a pixel value, using Dirichlet boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a reference to the pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily x},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or to a specified default value in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em x} & X-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em out\+\_\+value} & Default value returned if {\ttfamily }({\ttfamily x},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}) is outside image bounds. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_ae06c89401a8ca898b8bf72b082a1f88a}{operator()()}, except that an out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis returns the specified value {\ttfamily out\+\_\+value}.
\item Due to the additional boundary checking operation, this method is slower than \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_ae06c89401a8ca898b8bf72b082a1f88a}{operator()()}. Use it when you are {\itshape not} sure about the validity of the specified pixel coordinates. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds.

\end{DoxyWarning}

Return pixel value, using cubic interpolation and Dirichlet boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a cubicly-\/interpolated pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily fx},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or a specified default value in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. The cubic interpolation uses Hermite splines. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em fx} & d X-\/coordinate of the pixel value (float-\/valued). \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em out\+\_\+value} & Default value returned if {\ttfamily }({\ttfamily fx},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}) is outside image bounds. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to linear\+\_\+at\+X(float,int,int,int,const T) const, except that the returned pixel value is approximated by a {\itshape cubic} interpolation along the X-\/axis.
\item The type of the returned pixel value is extended to {\ttfamily float}, if the pixel type {\ttfamily T} is not float-\/valued. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

When \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a8a876b77c72080e4042aa427e8f86281}{depth()}{\ttfamily \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}} {\ttfamily 1}, the image is said to be {\itshape volumetric}.

Using an {\ttfamily int} is safer and prevents arithmetic traps possibly encountered when doing calculations involving {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variables. Access to the initial {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variable is possible (though not recommended) by {\ttfamily (\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}this).\+\_\+depth}.

Draw a 2D spline. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em x0} & X-\/coordinate of the starting curve point \\
\hline
{\em y0} & Y-\/coordinate of the starting curve point \\
\hline
{\em u0} & X-\/coordinate of the starting velocity \\
\hline
{\em v0} & Y-\/coordinate of the starting velocity \\
\hline
{\em x1} & X-\/coordinate of the ending curve point \\
\hline
{\em y1} & Y-\/coordinate of the ending curve point \\
\hline
{\em u1} & X-\/coordinate of the ending velocity \\
\hline
{\em v1} & Y-\/coordinate of the ending velocity \\
\hline
{\em color} & Pointer to {\ttfamily \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()}} consecutive values of type {\ttfamily T}, defining the drawing color. \\
\hline
{\em precision} & Curve drawing precision. \\
\hline
{\em opacity} & Drawing opacity. \\
\hline
{\em pattern} & An integer whose bits describe the line pattern. \\
\hline
{\em init\+\_\+hatch} & If {\ttfamily true}, init hatch motif. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The curve is a 2D cubic Bezier spline, from the set of specified starting/ending points and corresponding velocity vectors.
\item The spline is drawn as a sequence of connected segments. The {\ttfamily precision} parameter sets the average number of pixels in each drawn segment.
\item A cubic Bezier curve is sometimes defined by a set of 4 points \{ ({\ttfamily x0},{\ttfamily y0}), ({\ttfamily xa},{\ttfamily ya}), ({\ttfamily xb},{\ttfamily yb}), ({\ttfamily x1},{\ttfamily y1}) \} where ({\ttfamily x0},{\ttfamily y0}) is the starting point, ({\ttfamily x1},{\ttfamily y1}) is the ending point and ({\ttfamily xa},{\ttfamily ya}), ({\ttfamily xb},{\ttfamily yb}) are two {\itshape control} points. The starting and ending velocities ({\ttfamily u0},{\ttfamily v0}) and ({\ttfamily u1},{\ttfamily v1}) can be deduced easily from the control points as {\ttfamily u0} = ({\ttfamily xa} -\/ {\ttfamily x0}), {\ttfamily v0} = ({\ttfamily ya} -\/ {\ttfamily y0}), {\ttfamily u1} = ({\ttfamily x1} -\/ {\ttfamily xb}) and {\ttfamily v1} = ({\ttfamily y1} -\/ {\ttfamily yb}). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const}\ \textcolor{keywordtype}{unsigned}\ \textcolor{keywordtype}{char}\ color[]\ =\ \{\ 255,255,255\ \};}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img}}.draw\_spline(30,30,0,100,90,40,0,-\/100,color);}

\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyParagraph}

Test shared state of the pixel buffer. 

Return {\ttfamily true} if image instance has a shared memory buffer, and {\ttfamily false} otherwise. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item A shared image do not own his pixel buffer \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_abff69ea69a99d83c036decabeccea05d}{data()} and will not deallocate it on destruction.
\item Most of the time, a {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} image instance will {\itshape not} be shared.
\item A shared image can only be obtained by a limited set of constructors and methods (see list below). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Return pixel value, using linear interpolation and Dirichlet boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a linearly-\/interpolated pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily fx},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or a specified default value in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline

\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to at\+X(int,int,int,int,const T), except that the returned pixel value is approximated by a linear interpolation along the X-\/axis, if corresponding coordinates are not integers.
\item The type of the returned pixel value is extended to {\ttfamily float}, if the pixel type {\ttfamily T} is not float-\/valued. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

Transfer content of an image instance into another one. 

Transfer the dimensions and the pixel buffer content of an image instance into another one, and replace instance by an empty image. It avoids the copy of the pixel buffer when possible. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Destination image. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Pixel types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} of source and destination images can be different, though the process is designed to be instantaneous when {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are the same. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a76918ef9658da71040f29084bfe45de7}{CImg<float>}}\ src(256,256,1,3,0),\ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Construct\ a\ 256x256x1x3\ (color)\ image\ filled\ with\ value\ '0'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ dest(16,16);\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Construct\ a\ 16x16x1x1\ (scalar)\ image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{src.move\_to(dest);\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Now,\ 'src'\ is\ empty\ and\ 'dest'\ is\ the\ 256x256x1x3\ image}}

\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyParagraph}

Transfer content of an image instance into a new image in an image list. 

Transfer the dimensions and the pixel buffer content of an image instance into a newly inserted image at position {\ttfamily pos} in specified {\ttfamily CImg\+List$<$t$>$} instance. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em list} & Destination list. \\
\hline
{\em pos} & Position of the newly inserted image in the list. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item When optional parameter {\ttfamily pos} is omitted, the image instance is transferred as a new image at the end of the specified {\ttfamily list}.
\item It is convenient to sequentially insert new images into image lists, with no additional copies of memory buffer. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Implicitly cast an image into a {\ttfamily T\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}}. 

Implicitly cast a {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} instance into a {\ttfamily T\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}} or {\ttfamily const} {\ttfamily T\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}} pointer, whether the image instance is {\itshape const} or not. The returned pointer points on the first value of the image pixel buffer. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item It simply returns the pointer \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_abff69ea69a99d83c036decabeccea05d}{data()} to the pixel buffer.
\item This implicit conversion is convenient to test the empty state of images (\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_abff69ea69a99d83c036decabeccea05d}{data()} being {\ttfamily 0} in this case), e.\+g. 
\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a76918ef9658da71040f29084bfe45de7}{CImg<float>}}\ img1(100,100),\ img2;\ \textcolor{comment}{//\ 'img1'\ is\ a\ 100x100\ image,\ 'img2'\ is\ an\ empty\ image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keywordflow}{if}\ (img1)\ \{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Test\ succeeds,\ 'img1'\ is\ not\ an\ empty\ image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\ \ \textcolor{keywordflow}{if}\ (!img2)\ \{\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Test\ succeeds,\ 'img2'\ is\ an\ empty\ image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\ \ \ \ std::printf(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"{}'img1'\ is\ not\ empty,\ 'img2'\ is\ empty."{}});}
\DoxyCodeLine{\ \ \}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\}}

\end{DoxyCode}

\item It also allows to use brackets to access pixel values, without need for a {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$\+::operator\mbox{[}$\,$\mbox{]}()}, e.\+g. 
\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a76918ef9658da71040f29084bfe45de7}{CImg<float>}}\ \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img}}(100,100);}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const}\ \textcolor{keywordtype}{float}\ value\ =\ \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img}}[99];\ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Access\ to\ value\ of\ the\ last\ pixel\ on\ the\ first\ row}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img}}[510]\ =\ 255;\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \textcolor{comment}{//\ Set\ pixel\ value\ at\ (10,5)}}

\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyItemize}

Access to a pixel value. 

Return a reference to a located pixel value of the image instance, being possibly {\itshape const}, whether the image instance is {\itshape const} or not. This is the standard method to get/set pixel values in {\ttfamily CImg$<$\+T$>$} images. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em x} & X-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Range of pixel coordinates start from {\ttfamily (0,0,0,0)} to {\ttfamily (\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_aa80be550cee4daa91e5ccf73360b810e}{width()} -\/ 1,\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_aee97615afc19bf3e5f9fb3df72474e94}{height()} -\/ 1,\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a8a876b77c72080e4042aa427e8f86281}{depth()} -\/ 1,\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()} -\/ 1)}.
\item Due to the particular arrangement of the pixel buffers defined in CImg, you can omit one coordinate if the corresponding dimension is equal to {\ttfamily 1}. For instance, pixels of a 2D image (\doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a8a876b77c72080e4042aa427e8f86281}{depth()} equal to {\ttfamily 1}) can be accessed by {\ttfamily \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(x,y,c)}} instead of {\ttfamily \doxylink{namespacecimg__library_aff6e86f25b2615655070e2de4913e63e}{img(x,y,0,c)}}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking done in this operator, to make it as fast as possible. You {\itshape must} take care of out-\/of-\/bounds access by yourself, if necessary. For debugging purposes, you may want to define macro {\ttfamily \textquotesingle{}cimg\+\_\+verbosity\textquotesingle{}\texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}=3} to enable additional boundary checking operations in this operator. In that case, warning messages will be printed on the error output when accessing out-\/of-\/bounds pixels. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

Add values to image pixels, according to the values of the input image {\ttfamily img}.

{\em img} & Input image to add. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

\end{DoxyNote}

Construct an image list from two images. 

Return a new list of image ({\ttfamily \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImgList}{CImg\+List}} instance) containing exactly two elements\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item A copy of the image instance, at position \mbox{[}{\ttfamily 0}\mbox{]}.
\item A copy of the specified image {\ttfamily img}, at position \mbox{[}{\ttfamily 1}\mbox{]}.
\end{DoxyItemize}


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image that will be the second image of the resulting list. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The family of \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a213e6981f650b49a54df5e2de492ee8a}{operator,()} is convenient to easily create list of images, but it is also {\itshape quite} {\itshape slow} in practice (see warning below).
\item Constructed lists contain no shared images. If image instance or input image {\ttfamily img} are shared, they are inserted as new non-\/shared copies in the resulting list.
\item The pixel type of the returned list may be a superset of the initial pixel type {\ttfamily T}, if necessary. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Pipelining \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a213e6981f650b49a54df5e2de492ee8a}{operator,()} {\ttfamily N} times will perform {\ttfamily N} copies of the entire content of a (growing) image list. This may become very expensive in terms of speed and used memory. You should avoid using this technique to build a new \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImgList}{CImg\+List} instance from several images, if you are seeking for performance. \begin{DoxyItemize}

Test if two images have the same size and values. 

Return {\ttfamily true} if the image instance and the input image {\ttfamily img} have the same pixel values, even if the dimensions of the two images do not match. It returns {\ttfamily false} otherwise.

{\em img} & Input image to compare with. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The pixel buffer pointers \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_abff69ea69a99d83c036decabeccea05d}{data()} of the two compared images do not have to be the same for \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a791dd94364e72c65e1ff72f6433b954d}{operator==()} to return {\ttfamily true}. Only the dimensions and the pixel values matter. Thus, the comparison can be {\ttfamily true} even for different pixel types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Compute the projection of the instance matrix onto the specified dictionary. 

Find the best matching projection of selected matrix onto the span of an over-\/complete dictionary D, using the orthogonal projection or (opt. Orthogonal) Matching Pursuit algorithm. Instance image must a 2D-\/matrix in which each column represent a signal to project. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em dictionary} & A matrix in which each column is an element of the dictionary D. \\
\hline
{\em method} & Tell what projection method is applied. It can be\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item 0 = orthogonal projection (default).
\item 1 = matching pursuit.
\item 2 = matching pursuit, with a single orthogonal projection step at the end.
\item \texorpdfstring{$>$}{>}=3 = orthogonal matching pursuit where an orthogonal projection step is performed every \textquotesingle{}method-\/2\textquotesingle{} iterations. 
\end{DoxyItemize}\\
\hline
{\em max\+\_\+iter} & Sets the max number of iterations processed for each signal. If set to \textquotesingle{}0\textquotesingle{} (default), \textquotesingle{}max\+\_\+iter\textquotesingle{} is set to the number of dictionary columns. (only meaningful for matching pursuit and its variants). \\
\hline
{\em max\+\_\+residual} & Gives a stopping criterion on signal reconstruction accuracy. (only meaningful for matching pursuit and its variants). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A matrix W whose columns correspond to the sparse weights of associated to each input matrix column. Thus, the matrix product D\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}W is an approximation of the input matrix. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

\item If {\ttfamily cimg\+\_\+use\+\_\+tiff} is not defined at compile time the function uses CImg$<$\+T$>$\&save\+\_\+other(const char\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}).

Return the number of image channels. 

Return the number of image channels, i.\+e. the image dimension along the C-\/axis. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()} of an empty image is equal to {\ttfamily 0}.
\item \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()} is typically equal to {\ttfamily 1} when considering scalar-\/valued images, to {\ttfamily 3} for RGB-\/coded color images, and to {\ttfamily 4} for RGBA-\/coded color images (with alpha-\/channel). The number of channels of an image instance is not limited. The meaning of the pixel values is not linked up to the number of channels (e.\+g. a 4-\/channel image may indifferently stands for a RGBA or CMYK color image).
\item \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_a62c830749f7393e8371b78fb57e329b8}{spectrum()} returns an {\ttfamily int}, although the image spectrum is internally stored as an {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int}. Using an {\ttfamily int} is safer and prevents arithmetic traps possibly encountered when doing calculations involving {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variables. Access to the initial {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variable is possible (though not recommended) by {\ttfamily (\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}this).\+\_\+spectrum}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Return a C-\/string containing a list of all values of the image instance. 

Return a new {\ttfamily CImg$<$char$>$} image whose buffer \doxylink{structcimg__library_1_1CImg_abff69ea69a99d83c036decabeccea05d}{data()} is a {\ttfamily char\texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}} string describing the list of all pixel values of the image instance (written in base 10), separated by specified {\ttfamily separator} character. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em separator} & A {\ttfamily char} character which specifies the separator between values in the returned C-\/string. \\
\hline
{\em max\+\_\+size} & Maximum size of the returned image (or {\ttfamily 0} if no limits are set). \\
\hline
{\em format} & For float/double-\/values, tell the printf format used to generate the text representation of the numbers (or {\ttfamily 0} for default representation). \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The returned image is never empty.
\item For an empty image instance, the returned string is {\ttfamily "{}"{}}.
\item If {\ttfamily max\+\_\+size} is equal to {\ttfamily 0}, there are no limits on the size of the returned string.
\item Otherwise, if the maximum number of string characters is exceeded, the value string is cut off and terminated by character {\ttfamily \textquotesingle{}\textbackslash{}0\textquotesingle{}}. In that case, the returned image size is {\ttfamily max\+\_\+size + 1}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Return the variance of the pixel values. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em variance\+\_\+method} & Method used to estimate the variance. Can be\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily 0}\+: Second moment, computed as  $1/N \sum\limits_{k=1}^{N} (x_k - \bar x)^2 =
1/N \left( \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k^2 - \left( \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k \right)^2 / N \right)$ with $ \bar x = 1/N \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k $.
\item {\ttfamily 1}\+: Best unbiased estimator, computed as $\frac{1}{N - 1} \sum\limits_{k=1}^{N} (x_k - \bar x)^2 $.
\item {\ttfamily 2}\+: Least median of squares.
\item {\ttfamily 3}\+: Least trimmed of squares. 
\end{DoxyItemize}\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}
Because of structures such as edges in images it is recommended to use a robust variance estimation. The variance of the noise is estimated by computing the variance of the Laplacian  $(\Delta
I)^2 $ scaled by a factor $c$ insuring  $ c E[(\Delta I)^2]=
\sigma^2$ where $\sigma$ is the noise variance. 
\end{DoxyNote}
